headline: Four GOP Candidates for PA Governor demand debate rules
author: Brian Wilk
sentences:
I welcome a chance to debate, and to take our case – and our conservative Republican idea – to the people of the Keystone State.”
Melissa Hart (R) Candidate for Pennsylvania Governor
“We are proud to join with our fellow Republican candidates to participate only in debates that allow for the unbiased discussion of issues most important to our Commonwealth, respect the gubernatorial office, and whose purpose is to help voters gain insight into each candidate’s unique message.

(WJET/WFXP/YourErie.com) — Four Republican gubernatorial candidates for Pennsylvania Governor have made what another candidate called a “Diva-Esque demand.”
Bill McSwain, Lou Barletta, Jake Corman and Dave White’s campaigns all agreed to set a criteria that must be met before all candidates will attend any debate.

By adhering to the agreed upon guidelines, we can ensure that voters are not misled or unfairly influenced by moderators with a hostile or partisan agenda, and that the focus remains on candidates and their message for Pennsylvania.”
Rachel Tripp, Spokesperson for Bill McSwain for Governor Campaign.

“A number of the men running for Governor – candidates who will leap at a chance to bemoan “cancel culture” or “safe spaces” if they think it will earn them a spot on cable news that night- issued a peculiar statement today selling out conditions for their participation in any debate.

Mercyhurst University Political Professor Dr. Joe Morris said this is acceptable at some level, primaries are supposed to be party affairs.

I have enough faith in the good sense of the voters of our Commonwealth that I am not able to hide behind the curtains of a debate stage until I am confident everything will follow a predetermined script.

The criteria includes:
Any moderator must be a registered Republican and live in Pennsylvania
The moderator has not spoken negatively or worked for a company that has spoken about any of the candidates.
Competitions are also used as an opportunity to really test these candidates and see how well they are going to do against their rival party in the general election.

The media aren’t motivated to select the best candidate to beat Josh Shapiro, but Republicans are.”
Tim Murtaugh, Senior Advisor to Lou Barletta Campaign.
I don’t think that this is doing the Republican party any favors,” said Dr. Joe Morris, Political Analyst, Mercyhurst University.
I am not afraid of tough questions, and I will not demand to see the registration card of the question before I answer.
“Republicans ought to be the ones who control a Republican process to choose the Republican nominee for governor.
“On the other hand, I think this poses a real problem for the Republican primary.
They have not endorsed or donated to the candidates on stage.
No questions with answers shorter than 30 seconds.
